\begin{align*}
(\omega, D(\omega)) \quad &\text{basis} \\
\nabla^2(\omega) &= \frac{1}{4\lambda(1-\lambda)}\omega + \frac{2\lambda-1}{\lambda(1-\lambda)}D(\omega). \\
\text{horizontal section is} \\
f(\lambda)\lambda(1-\lambda)\omega - f'(\lambda)\lambda(1-\lambda)\nabla(\omega) \\
\text{for hypergeometric function} \\
f(\lambda) &= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \prod_{i=0}^{n-1} \left(\frac{i+\frac{1}{2}}{\lambda+1}\right)^2 \lambda^n.
\end{align*}

\begin{align*}
&\text{This is a Theorem: after p-adic completion, [Bhatt-S.]} \\
&\text{in full, [Wagner]} \\
&\text{Example: Legendre family} \\
&\text{of elliptic curves} \\
&R = \mathbb{Z}\left[\frac{1}{2}, \lambda\right]\left[\frac{1}{\lambda(1-\lambda)}\right] \\
&\text{Fil}^1_{\text{dR}} = H^0(X, \Omega^1_{X/R}) \ni \omega = \frac{dx}{y} \\
&H^2_{\text{dR}}(X/R) \supset \text{free rk 2.} \\
&\text{adele glue, over } (R\otimes)\left[\frac{1}{q-1}\right], \text{ get constant out of } dR \text{ when.} \\
&X/R: \text{ elliptic curve with affine model} \\
&y^2 = x(x-1)(x-\lambda).
\end{align*}
% diagram from board_hh_mm_ss_000.jpg

This admits natural $q$-deformations, eg
\[
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \prod_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( \frac{[i+1]_q^2}{[i+1]_q} \right)^2 \lambda^n \text{ satisfies 2nd order }
\]
\[
\text{ $q$-difference equation, Heun/Garnier Fuchs $q$. }
\]
Question: Are these explicit $q$-deformations related to abstract $q$-de Rham cohomology?

This admits natural $q$-deformations, eg
\[
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \prod_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( \frac{[i+2]_q}{[i+1]_q} \right)^2 \lambda^n \text{ satisfies 2nd order } q\text{-difference equation,}
\]
\[
\text{Question: Are these explicit } q\text{-deformations related to abstract } q\text{-de Rham cohomology?}
\]

Question: Are these explicit $q$-deformations related to abstract $q$-de Rham cohomology?

Answer: Yes, Shirai Cohomology?

This admits natural $q$-deformations, e.g.
\[
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \prod_{i=0}^{n} \left( \frac{[i+2]_q}{[i+1]_q} \right)^2 \lambda^n \text{ satisfies 2nd order } q\text{-difference equation.}
\]
Question: Are these explicit $q$-deformations. the family Riemann Fuchs eqn.

This admits natural $q$-deformations, eg

\[
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \prod_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( \frac{(i+\frac{1}{2})^2}{(i+1)q} \right)^2 \lambda^n \text{ satisfies 2nd order } q\text{-difference equation,}
\]

Question: Are these explicit $q$-deformations. the family Riemann Fuchs eq.

This admits natural $q$-deformations, eg

\[
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \prod_{i=0}^{n-1} \left( \frac{(i+\frac{1}{2})_q}{(i+1)_q} \right)^2 \lambda^n \text{ satisfies 2nd order } q\text{-difference equation,}
\]
